On the counter in a rinsed out olive jar filled with water, are three fa red roses. The TITLE APPEARS IN BLACK SCRIPT AGAINST THE  WHITE BACKGROUND.

(barely discernable) Three times they cancel the order  with me, and three times they come  back. Who they kidding? They cheap,  cheap, cheap. The other bread they  get is no good. They save pennies.  Everybody complain and they come  back. "Zito, your bread is the best."  They're like children stupid in school  who cannot learn. The water. It's  the water. You buy bread in Hoboken,  you get Hoboken water. Hoboken water  is dry. Ask anybody who knows. Ask  your father. He knows.

During Zito's plaintive words, WE LEAVE the roses and MOV DOWN the counter TO a calculator being tapped very effici with the eraser end of pencil. When the results appear, t pencil notes the figure in a threadbare old ledger.
He's a middle-aged Italian man with a kind face. But it's early in the day, and he's already been working for hours so he's a little tired and disgruntled.
You want me to make you some coffee?

head_text.subj: NOW WE SEE LORETTA FOR THE FIRST TIME

text: She's entering a few final figures in the ledger. LORETTA Italian, 37. Her hair black, done in a dated style, is fl with grey. She's dressed in sensible but unfashionable cl of a dark color.
What d'you know about coffee? Gimme  a loaf of bread.
Loretta emerges with her little weathered leather bookkee satchel and a loaf of Zito bread in a white paper bag. Sh moves off briskly.
This is a little Italian funeral parlor.

A generic little room filled with many flowers and wreath many folding chairs, a few OLD PEOPLE sitting and, up fro the star of the show, the CORPSE on display in his gold a formica casket. Before the casket is a little kneeler. We discover an OLD LADY there, who crosses herself and rises She goes and sits by RUBY, another old women. She leans o and says.
He looks great.
That Al Conti is a genius.
First WE SEE a name plate on a desk. The plate reads ALFO CONTI. We HEAR his VOICE.
I am a genius.
The SHOT WIDENS TO INCLUDE the loaf of bread which is hal cut up and being buttered. Next to the bread are two stea mugs of coffee. We HEAR the subdued TAPPING of Loretta's  tabulations.
If you're such an artistic genius,  why can't you keep track of your  receipts? How am I going to do your  income tax?
I am an artistic genius.

The SHOT WIDENS and now we can see Al Conti and Loretta  sitting at the desk having Zito's buttered bread and mugs coffee. Loretta's got her calculator going and is enterin figures in Al's black, gold-lettered ledger.
If you're an artistic genius, how  come you got butter on your tie?
He looks down and sees the stain. He's at a loss.
Give it here. I'll give you this,  Al, you make good coffee.
She downs her coffee, accepts the stained tie which Al ha taken off, and slams the ledger shut.

We are looking at a wall of dry-cleaned clothes bags. The are hanging from an automated grid. As we watch, the wall starts to move off to the left. A gap appears where no cl are hung. The gap creates visual frame. In the frame is  ROBERT. He is operating the grid with a little stick shif He stops it and takes down a garment. He leaves the frame heading off to the counter. When he moves away, WE SEE th Loretta is behind him, working her calculator, entering i ledger. She slams the ledger shut, waves goodbye, and goe After beat she reappears, produces Conti's tie, says some to Robert, who is out of view, leaves the tie, and
WE SEE a cleaver whacking an oxtail into section. Now WE SEE Loretta, a few feet away, tabulating on a chop block that is partially obscured by a row of hanging rabb unskinned.
A long white box is being filled with red roses. We HEAR FLORIST'S VOICE.
Red roses. Very romantic. The man  who sends these knows what he's doing.
Now WE SEE Loretta tabulating and the Florist working on box of roses.
The man who sends those spends a lot  of money on something that ends up  in the garbage can.
The Florist gives her a look and then smiles.
I'm glad everybody ain't like you,  Loretta. I'd be outta business.
Without me, you'd be out of business.  I like flowers.

She gives him a sudden, brief, blinding smile. It's the f time we've seen her smile. She has gold work around one o her two front teeth. The Florist grunts and hands her a r rose. Camera moves close to Loretta and the rose.
A red neon sign hangs in the window. It's a quaint downstairs restaurant in Greenwich Village. YOUNG COUPLE stop, look at the menu, become more interest in each other, kiss, and decide to go in.
White tablecloths and dark green walls, a tiny bar up by door. The WAITERS all look a little alike. That's because they're all related. The place is about half full, and bu along pleasantly.

A VIOLIN PLAYS a melancholy Neapolitan air. MR. JOHNNY and Loretta sit at a table for two talking qui They have their menus and glasses of red wine. Mr. Johnny Italian, around 42. His wavy salt-and pepper hair is  impeccably combed back; but there is so much that it thre to fall forward someday and engulf his face. He is wearin pinky ring, a dark suit, a gold watch, and, on his face, mustache and a look of incredible seriousness. Loretta is Italian, 37. Her black hair, done in a dated style, is fl with grey. She is wearing a dark blouse, black skirt, and high heels. One of her teeth is framed with gold work. Mr. Johnny is really timid of life, an overgrown boy, who hides these qualities behind a veil of dignity. Loretta is tough and efficient, loyal and watchful; she  watches out for Mr. Johnny, and defends him against life. BOBO, an Old World Italian waiter, comes over to take the order.
Are you ready?
Hello, Bobo. How are you tonight?
Very good, Mr. Johnny.
We will both have the Salad Ticino.
Uh-huh
And I'll have the special fish.
You don't want the fish.
No?
It's the oily fish tonight. Not before  the plane ride.
Maybe you're right.
Give him the manicotta, Bobo. Me,  too.
Yes, Miss Loretta.
(to Mr. Johnny) That will give you a base. For your  stomach. You eat that oily fish, you  go up in the air, halfway to Sicily  you'll be green and your hands will  be sweating.
(smiles) You look after me.
They HEAR a distinguished MAN'S VOICE rise out of the bab They turn and look. The man's name is PERRY.
Perry is a university professor. PATRICIA is his  girlfriend/student. He's in his 50's. She's about 25 year younger. She's getting her coat on in a huff.
Patricia, please don't go!
What do you think I am, a talking  dog?
I was just making a point about the  way you said... the way you stated  your aspirations.
You can kiss my aspirations!  Professor!
She storms out, leaving Perry muttering to himself.
Kiss my aspirations. Oh, very clever.  The height of cleverness. Waiter!
An abnormally SHY WAITER stops.
Yes?
Could you do away with her dinner,  and any evidence of her, and bring  me an big glass of vodka?
But absolutely!
THE SHY WAITER begins to efficiently clear.

head_text.subj: MR. JOHNNY AND LORETTA EXCHANGE A GLANCE

text: Mr. Johnny is amused. Bobo serves them their salad.
A man who can't control his woman is  funny.
She was too young for him.
Mr. Johnny considers this a point well taken.

head_text.subj: BOBO AND HIS NEPHEW EDDIE STAND NEAR THE KITCHEN

text: Which can be seen through a serving window. They can look out over the restaurant tables. Bobo is melancholy and  philosophical. EDDIE is a young waiter.
What'samatter, Uncle Bobo?
Tonight Mr. Johnny's gonna propose  marriage.
How you know that?
He arranged it with me. When he asks  her, then he'll wave to me and I'll  bring champagne. Good bachelor  customer for twenty years. But who  knows? Maybe he'll lose courage.
Heavy duty stuff.

head_text.subj: PERRY, FEELING NO PAIN, COLLARS THE SHY WAITER

text: He holds out his empty glass.
Can I get another one of these?
Definitely!
Perry takes his arm.
May I presume to ask you a question?
Sure!
Do you have a girlfriend?
I am alone in the world.
Perry lets go of his arm. He and the Shy Waiter commisera a moment. Then, wordlessly, the Shy Waiter goes.
That's very sad.
BOBO IS CLEARING THE REMAINS OF MR. JOHNNY'S DINNER. He's already cleared Loretta's.
How's things?
Fine, Bobo. We'll take the check.
No, I want to see the dessert cart.
Very good.
Bobo goes. Loretta is surprised.
You never have dessert.
Never is a long time.
Mr. Johnny is uneasy. He massages his head.
What's the matter?
My scalp is not getting enough blood  sometimes.
Loretta looks at him strangely. Bobo rolls up the dessert cart. WE SEE Loretta and Mr. Johnny through the frame of dessert cart. They turn and look at the desserts.
Have Something.
I shouldn't.
Will you marry me?
What?
Will you marry me?
Bobo, take the cart away.
He does.
(continuing) Are you proposing marriage to me?
Yes?
You know I was married and that my  husband died. But what you don't  know is I think he and I had Bad  Luck.
What do you mean?
We got married at the City Hall and  I think it gave bad luck the whole  marriage.
I don't understand.
Right from the start we didn't do it  right. Could you kneel down?
On the floor?
Yes, on the floor.
This is a good suit.
I helped you buy it. It came with  two pairs of pants. It's for luck,  Johnny. When you propose marriage to  a woman, you should kneel down.
Alright.

Mr. Johnny slowly gets out of his chair. There's not enou room for him to kneel down. He has to ask two off-duty PR WRESTLERS who are eating dinner to move their chairs. The do so with bemused expressions. Their names are BOB and M

I woulda sprung for a ring if it was  me.

head_text.subj: BOBO AND EDDIE STAND NEAR THE KITCHEN WATCHING

text: She's got him on his knees. He's  ruining his suit.
You could use your pinky ring.
I like this ring.
You propose to a woman you should  offer her a ring of engagement.
Mr. Johnny takes off the ring and holds it out to her.
Loretta. Loretta Castorini Clark. On  my knees. In front of all these  people. Will you marry me?
She meekly accepts the ring from him and takes his hands.
Yes, Johnny. Yes, John Anthony  Cammareri. I will marry you. I will  be your wife.
Mr. Johnny slowly stands up, brushes off his knees. The  restaurant has fallen utterly silent. Loretta smiles. The embrace. Loretta kisses him quickly.

head_text.subj: A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN, SUSAN, IS MAUDLIN FROM THE PROPOSAL

text: Bobo stands very near her table. She is about to applaud proposal. She brings her hands together. Bobo's hand flas out and neatly captures her hands before they can part ag The single sound dies abruptly in the silent room.
Mr. Johnny is in control now. He looks around once, regal
Bobo! The check!

head_text.subj: PERRY AND THE SHY WAITER LOOK AT MR. JOHNNY AND LORETTA

text: I feel like I have just witnessed a  car accident.
The Shy Waiter sits down at Perry's table.
When I was twenty-seven years old,  in Jersey City, I asked a woman to  marry me. She had red hair. She  smelled a jasmine. She wore black  shoes with pointy white tips.
What happened?
She didn't hear me. She asked me to  repeat, so she could understand what  I said. But I wouldn't repeat it.  Outta shyness. So I'm a bachelor.
He's helping her on with her coat.
What time is it?
Seven-thirty.
So we'll pick up the car, we'll make  the plane in plenty of time.
Mr. Johnny puts on his coat.
My mother will be happy I'm getting  married.
Bobo approaches with the bucket of champagne. He's fluste
I forgot to bring the champagne, Mr.  Johnny.
I forgot to wave. We'll have it at  the wedding.
Loretta driving and Mr. Johnny sitting beside her. In the back seat are two suitcases.
What about the wedding?
My mother is dying. When she is dead,  I'll come back and we'll be married.
How near is she to death?
A week. Two weeks. No more.
Then let's set the date.
How about a month from today?
Must it be so definite? Can't we  just say that we will be married  when I get back?
Where? At the City Hall? No! I want  the whole wedding or we will have  Bad Luck. For a whole wedding to be  planned, a date must be set.
Alright. A month. In a month.
A month from today?
Yeah.
I'll take care of it, Johnny. I'll  take care of the whole thing. All  you have to do is show up.

Oh, you're not going. You're staying.
No, I'm going.
The Shawfish?

Then, I suppose the time has come  say it's been nice Dwight Lionel.  It's been everything. Oh, Dwight,  I'm frightened.
I know, I am so sorry for so many  things. I love you, Moira. I love  you. I love you.

(over P.A. System) International Flight Number Six-ohfour  boarding for Rome and Palermo at  Gate Twenty-six.

text: Call me when you get in.
I'll call you when I get to Mama's  house.
You've made me very happy, Johnny.
He takes a piece of paper from his wallet.
There's one thing about this wedding  I want you to do. Call this number.  It's a business number. Ask for Ronny.  Invite him to the wedding.
Who is he?
He's my younger brother.
You have a brother?
We haven't spoken in five years.  There was some bad blood. I want you  to call him and invite him to the  wedding. Will you do it?
Sure.
This is the last call for  International Flight Number Six-ohfour  boarding at Gate Twenty-six for Rome  and Palermo.
I've got to go.
He clumsily kisses her. Then he quickly turns and leaves. She waves, but he doesn't look back.
Close shot on plane's wheels and under belly as it slowly begins to move. Red lights are flashing.

head_text.subj: AN OLD ITALIAN CRONE IS LOOKING OUT THE TERMINAL WINDOW

text: In the background we see the accordion like ramp that was loading to the departing aircraft, slowly fold up. Lorett walks up beside her, and looks out the window, too. The c is dressed in black and has a black scarf on her head. The Crone notices Loretta.
Do you have someone on that plane?
Yeah. (smiles) My fiance.

I have put a curse on that plane. My  sister is on that plane. I have put  a curse on that plane that it should  explode. Burn on fire and fall into  the sea. Fifty years ago she stole a  man from me. Today she told me that  she didn't even love him. She took  him to feel strong with me. Now she  goes back to Sicily. I have cursed  her that the green Atlantic water  should swallow her up.
I don't believe in curses.
(smiles) Neither do I.
The plane takes off. Loretta looks after it anxiously. Al her hopes are on that plane.

location: A PARKING GARAGE IN LITTLE ITALY

text: The LTD pulls into the entrance and Loretta gets out. An  ATTENDANT appears.
Mr. Johnny's, right?
Right. The key's in it.
Good night.
Night.
Loretta walks of into the night.
Camera frames the window with a sweetheart in neon.
Loretta walks up the street and enters the store.
Loretta walks in. IRV and LOTTE, the middle-aged couple w own and run the place, are having an argument.
I've seen how you look at her and it  isn't right.
How do I look at her? (to Loretta) Can I help you?
A split of Moet.
(to IRV) Like a wolf.
(getting the split) Like a wolf, huh? You never seen a  wolf in your life.
(to Loretta) That's seven-fifty-seven.
Loretta pays and waits for her change.
I seen a wolf in everybody I ever  met and I see a wolf in you.
(giving the change) That makes ten. Thanks. Have a nice  night.
You, too.
Loretta walks out.
You know what I see in you, Lotte?
What?
The girl I married.
Lotte, caught off-guard, blushes.

It's a big, old eccentric, three-story corner house. To o side, it's got a qated arch that leads to an inner courty where three cars could park. It's got two cast-iron balco About a third of the windows in the house are lit. From within can be HEARD the faint strains of VICKI CARR  SINGING and one DOG BARKING. Loretta appears, carrying  champagne, approaches the front door, unlocks it, and goe in.

VICKI CARR is SINGING "IT MUST BE HIM." The front hall is typical of big old brownstones. There's big old oak coat rack with a built-in mirror and an umbre stand. There are several coats hanging from it. The floor littered with boots. There's also a side table. On the table is a large cut-glass bowl filled with a coup of pounds of hard candy. Loretta comes in and takes off her coat. A single MAD HOW is HEARD, followed by a PANDEMONIUM OF BARKING. FIVE DOGS charge into the hall to greet Loretta. They are totally  cockeyed, crackpot mutts. Their names are JUDAS, LUCY, LE FATBOY, AND JONES.
Hello, boys and girls. Guess what  happened to me?
The VOICE of the OLD MAN is heard calling out from upstai
How long must I wait? Quanto tempo  devo aspettare?
The Five Dogs turn away from Loretta and charge up the st toward the voice. Loretta walks toward the living room.

This is the source of the Vicki Carr song, which is just  ending. COSMO CASTORINI, Loretta's father is just turning off the old stereo. He is a powerful man, about 65, with huge shock of white hair and gold wire glasses. He's wear a big old red silk robe over blue pajamas, and royal blue slippers. The room it filled with lumpy upholstered furni once grand, now threadbare; shawls and doilies cover hole in failing fabric. There's a fireplace containing a dying fire. Cosmo's wing chair, with his newspaper on it, is be a lit fringed lamp. Cosmo sees Loretta as she comes in.
Hi.
He sits in his chair and puts his feet up on an old  needlepoint ottoman. He starts to read the paper.
Where's Ma?
Bed.
You're not sleepy?
I can't sleep anymore. It's too much  like death.
Pop, I got news.
Cosmo puts down the paper and takes his feet off the otto
Alright. Let's go in the kitchen.
Cosmo gets up and heads for the kitchen. He hums and cont as Loretta opens champagne.

Loretta and Cosmo sit at the kitchen table. It's a big ti table with a black-and-white design. Loretta has put two fashioned champagne glasses on the table, the split of  champagne, a bag of sugar cubes, and a bottle of bitters. She pours the champagne, drops a little lump of sugar int each glass, and adds a dash of bitters. She hands one of drinks to Cosmo.
Here. (She Toasts) Ti amo. (Translated: I love  you.)
Ti amo.
You look tired.
What's your news?
I'm getting married.
Again?
Yeah.
You did this once it didn't work  out.
The guy died.
What killed him?
He got hit by a bus.

No! Bad luck! Your Ma and I been  married fifty-two years an nobody  died. You were married, what, two  years, and somebody is dead. Don't  get married again, Loretta. It don't  work out for you. Who's the man?
Johnny Cammareri.
Him? He's a big baby. Why isn't he  here with you telling me?
He's flying to Sicily. His mother's  dying.
More Bad Luck! I don't like his face,  Loretta. I don't like his lips. When  he smiles I can't see his teeth.  When will you do it?
In a month.
I won't come.
You've got to come. You've got to  give me away.
I didn't give you away the first  time.

And maybe that's why I had the Bad  Luck. Maybe if you gave me away, and  I got married in a church, in a  wedding dress, instead of at the  City Hall with strangers standing  outside the door, maybe then I  wouldn't had the Bad Luck I had.
Maybe.
I didn't have no wedding cake, no  reception or nothing. Johnny got  down on his knees and proposed to me  at The Grand Ticino.
He did?
Yeah.
That don't sound like Johnny. Where's  the ring?
Loretta shows it. Cosmo examines it.
Here.
It looks stupid. It's a pinky ring.  It's a man's ring.
It's temporary.
Everything is temporary. That don't  excuse nothing.
So you'll come to the wedding, right?
Let's go tell your Mother.
She smiles. He doesn't. They rise from the table.
The door to the hall opens, and the light from without di illuminates a massive four-poster bed. Cosmo enters, foll by Loretta. He speaks into the dark a calm and measured  summons.
Rose. Rose. Rose. Rose.

A lamp is switched on by the bed. By ROSE. Rose is in her 60'S, and is very, very beautiful. Her abundant white tre frame a face of porcelain delicacy. She's wearing an old and richly beautiful white nightgown
Who's dead?
Nobody. Loretta is getting married.
Again? Johnny Cammareri.
Cosmo goes and sits on the bed.
I don't like him.
You're not gonna marry him, Cosmo.  Do you love him, Loretta?
No.
Good. When you love them they drive  you crazy cause they know they can.  But you like him?
Oh yeah. He's a sweet man. I wanna  have a big church wedding, Ma. And a  reception.
And who's gonna pay for that?
Pop.
WHAT?
Rose starts laughing.
Father of the bride pays.
Cosmo walks out.
I have no money!
You're rich as Roosevelt. You're  just cheap, Cosmo.
Cosmo shouts from the stairs.
I won't pay for nothing.
He didn't used to be cheap. He thinks  if he holds on to his money, he will  never die.
It's his duty as a father to pay for  my wedding, Ma ...
VICKI CARR, SINGING "IT MUST BE HIM", starts playing. Ros looks weary.
Now he's gonna play that damn Vicki  Carr record. And then when he comes  to bed, he won't touch me.

The first golden rays of sunlight touch the great old hou The front door opens. Close shot of dogs coming into came as door opens. The OLD MAN comes out. The Old Man, who is Cosmo's father, is 83 years old. He is taking the Five Do out for their morning walk. He has their five leashes bun in one hand. In the other hand, even though it is a cloud November morning, he open black umbrella. He walks off do the block with the dogs.

location: A SMALL CITY PARK SURROUNDED BY HURRICANE FENCE

text: The Old Man and the Five Dogs appear and enter the park. approaches a park bench where FELIX and LUCY are already  sitting. Felix and Lucy are about the same age as the Old Man. They each have a well-behaved DOG. When the Old Man  sits down, he lets the Five Dogs go. The Dogs run off, BA like mad.
It's wrong to just let them go.
(ignoring Felix) Good morning, Lucy.
Good morning.
They run around, they mess up the  whole park.
What do you want me to do? Pick up  after five dogs? I'm eighty-three  years old. God in his heaven  understands that I cannot pick up  after five dogs.
You have too many dogs.
The dogs can be HEARD in the distance. It sounds like the killing each other.
(goes back to ignoring  Felix) Lucy. There are big things going on  in my house. My granddaughter Loretta,  the only daughter of my son Cosmo,  has engaged herself to be married a  second time.
I have heard that Johnny Cammareri  got down on his knees in The Grand  Ticino and proposed to her.
My son does not like this Johnny  Cammareri. He says he is a big baby.
You should have one dog. Like Lucy.  Like me. I wish I hadda gun. If I  hadda gun, I would shoot four of  your dogs.
The Old Man makes a low, threatening noise.
Don't fight.
My granddaughter wants my son to pay  for the wedding. But he does not  want to pay.
He should pay.
I don't know.
He owes her a wedding from the first  time when there was none.
Maybe. I don't know. He has not asked  my advice. If he asks my advice, I  don't know what I will say.
The SOUND of the DOGS becomes intense again.
I won't have to shoot those dogs.  They will kill each other.
You think so, huh, Stupid? Those  dogs love each other.

The gates in the big archway are opened from the inside. It's Cosmo. He's wearing a good but old-fashioned suit, a overcoat, and a homburg. He's pulled his car, a 1965 blac Buick, up to the gate. Now that he has the gates open, he gets in the car and drives out to the curb. He gets out a goes back to lock the gates. As he does this, the Old Man approaches the house with the Five dogs and the open umbr The Old Man and the Dogs go to the front door of the hous Cosmo goes to the door of his car. The two men, father an son, see each other at the moment they grab their respect door handles. They each raise a hand in greeting; it is t same gesture for both men, an eccentric chopping motion. Then they open their respective doors. The Old Man disapp within the house. Cosmo drives slowly away in his car.

The spatula reappears and lifts the resul from the pan, and slides them onto two small dark blue pl Now WE SEE that Loretta is just finishing setting the tin table for two. In the b.g., Rose is turning away from the big, old-fashioned six range gas stove where an old speck coffee pot is steaming up a sun-drenched window. Rose com toward the table with the laden blue plates. She's wearin nice old apron over a blue housedress. She's thoughtful. As Rose comes to the table, Loretta in a blue denim work  shirt and pants, goes to the stove and gets the coffee. A Rose puts breakfast on the table, she speaks to Loretta,  who's at the stove.
Will you live here?
No.
Why not?
Pop don't like Johnny.
Loretta returns with the coffeepot to the table, and pour Then she takes the pot back to the stove.
So we'll sell the house.
I got married before, you didn't  sell.
Loretta comes to the table. They sit down to breakfast.
Grandma was still alive. Chiro was  still home going to school. Now he's  married and gone to Florida. If you  and Johnny moved in, had a baby...
I'm thirty-seven years old.
What's thirty-seven? I had Chiro  after I was thirty-seven. It ain't  over till it's over.
Johnny has a big apartment. We'll  live there.
And we'll sell the house.
I'd like to stay, Ma. I love the  house. But Pop don't like Johnny.
No. He don't.
The WALL PHONE in the kitchen RINGS. Loretta goes and ans it.
Hello? Yea, this is Loretta Castorini -  yeah. Is that you Johnny?

Mr. Johnny is calling on an old European-style phone. In b.g. is the sickbed. In the sickbed lies VESTA, Mr. Johnn mother, her grey hair spread out on a golden pillow. By the bed are THREE MOURNERS, old crones dressed in blac One clutches a missal, the other two clutch rosaries. All three are grieving in a steady low wordless whine. Mr. Jo speaks into the phone in a confidential manner. There is  some long-distance CRACKLE.
Ssh, it's me. I'm calling from the  deathbed of my mother.
How was your plane ride?
The waitresses were very nice. (glances over at his  mother) My mother is slipping away.
(calling to the Heavens) Quanto tempo devo aspettare? (now she aims more at  Johnny) How long must I wait?!
I can't talk long.
Have you told her we're getting  married?
Not yet. I'm waiting till a moment  when she's peaceful.
We HEAR Loretta's VOICE over his receiver.
Just don't wait until she's dead.
Have you called my brother?
Not yet.
Will you do it today? Call him, make  him come to the wedding. Five years  is too long for bad blood between  brothers. Nothing can replace your  family. I see that now.
Alright. I'll call him. Today. Listen,  Johnny. Call me after you tell your  mother. Alright? Alright. And don't  stand directly under the sun. You've  got your hat, use your hat. Alright.  Bye-bye.
Loretta hangs up the phone. She thinks. Rose speaks from table, where she's still sitting.
How's the mother?
She's dying. But I could still hear  her big mouth.
Did he tell her?
Not yet. That old lady makes him  sweat. (to herself) Where's that card?
Rose gets up and takes the dishes to the sink, Loretta fi in her pocket and comes out with the business card Mr. Jo gave her. She dials the number.
Who Are you calling?
(INTERCUT W/LORETTA IN KITCHEN)
CHRISSY, a woman with a Queens accent, answers.
Cammareri's Bake Shop.
Is Ronny there?
Hold on. (yells into intercom) Ronny, the phone!
(INTERCUT W/LORETTA IN KITCHEN)
Yeah, this is Ronny.
I'm calling for your brother Johnny.  He's getting married and he wants  you to come.
There's a long pause. Ronny's voice returns, hoarse with  emotion.
Why didn't he call himself?
He's in Palermo.
What's wrong can never be made right. (hangs up phone)
Let me come and talk to you.
Loretta hangs up the phone. She looks at the card again,  makes a decision and pockets the card.
As Cosmo drives away. He's in a very good mood. He's  WHISTLING. He laughs to himself.
And the street in front of it. Loretta arrives. She's wea a long, navy-blue cloth coat and a knit hat. She looks up the sign and at the business card in her hand, and enters the shop.

It's a nice Italian bake shop. Three Italian women, CHRIS BARBARA, and MA wait on THREE WOMEN SHOPPERS at the count CHRISSY and BARBARA are in their late 20's or early 30's; is old, old. Loretta comes in and speaks to CHRISSY.
Is Ronny Cammareri here?
He down at the ovens. What do you  want?
I would like to speak to him.
Chrissy comes out and Loretta follows. They walk around t an outdoor staircase that descends into the sidewalk. Chr shouts down.
Hey, RONNY.

location: AN OLD DOOR AT THE FOOT OF THE STAIRCASE

text: The door slides open, revealing ROCCO, a baker missing a teeth. He is surrounded by bread.
What!
Somebody to see Ronny.
Rocco slides back the door all the way. Chrissy and Loret make their way past him. He slides the door three quarter shut behind them.

There are two coal-fired ovens, one at either end of the  room. There is a large wooden table roughly center. And  various pieces of baking equipment, dough-mixers, etc.,  scattered willy-nilly. And everywhere there is bread. PIETRO, a baker, is working at one of the ovens with a lo wooden spatula. RONNY is working at the other oven. Actually, he is just staring in the open door at the baki bread and burning coals. He's dressed in black jeans stre with flour, a white restaurant shirt, white cotton gloves and around his neck, a red handkerchief. He is black-hair handsome and intense.
Ronny!
What!
Somebody here to see you.
Ronny turns and takes in Loretta.
Have you come from my brother?
Yes.
Why?
I'm going to marry him.
You are going to marry my brother?
Yes. Do you want...
I have no life.
Excuse me.
I have no life. My brother Johnny  took my life from me.
I don't understand.
Everything in the oven room has stopped and everyone is  watching.
And now he's getting married. He has  his, he's getting his. And he wants  me to come? What is life?
He picks up the wooden spatula and slides it into the ove
I didn't come here to upset you.
Ronny slides a bunch of loaves out of the oven on the spa turns them around, and slides them back in.

They say bread is life. So I bake  bread, bread, bread. (He's picking up loaves  of bread from one of  the boxes on the  floor, and casually  tossing them across  the room.) And the years go by! By! By! And I  sweat and shovel this stinking dough  in and outta this hot hole in the  wall and I should be so happy, huh,  sweetheart? You want me to come to  the wedding of my brother Johnny?!!  Where is my wedding? Chrissy! Over  by the wall! Gimme the big knife!
No, Ronny!
Barbara appears in the doorway and comes down the stairs  into the room.
Gimme the big knife! I'm gonna cut  my throat!
Maybe I should come back another  time.
No, I want you to see this! I want  you to watch me kill myself so you  can tell my brother on his wedding  day! Chrissy, gimme the big knife!
I tell you I won't do it!
(to Loretta) Do you know about me?
Oh, Mr. Cammareri!
Nothing is anybody's fault, but things  happen. (holds up his left  hand to Loretta) Look.
He pulls off the glove. The hand is made of wood.

It's wood. It's fake. Five years ago  I was engaged to be married. Johnny  came in here, he ordered bread from  me. I put it in the slicer and I  talked with him and my hand got caught  cause I wasn't paying attention. The  slicer chewed off my hand. It's funny  'cause - when my fiance saw that I  was maimed, she left me for another  man.
That's the bad blood between you and  Johnny?
That's it.
But that wasn't Johnny's fault.

I don't care! I ain't no freakin  monument to justice! I lost my hand,  I lost my bride! Johnny has his hand,  Johnny has his bride! You come in  here and you want me to put away my  heartbreak and forget?
He goes to the big table, which is floured and covered wi bread. He sweeps everything off the tabletop during the n

Is it just a matter of time till a  man opens his eyes and gives up his  one dream of happiness? Maybe. Maybe.  All I have... Have you come here,  Stranger, Bride of my Brother, to  take these last few loaves from my  table? Alright. Alright.

The table is bare. He stares at it blankly. He wanders aw to the back room where the flour sacks are kept. We hear single sob escape him from that room, and then silence. Everyone in the oven room looks after him. Then Chrissy  approaches Loretta. She holds the big knife at her side.
This is the most tormented man I  have ever known. I am in love with  this man. He doesn't know that. I  never told him cause he can never  love anybody since he lost his hand  and his girl.
She holds out the knife.
Here. Why don't you just kill him?  It would be so much more kind than  coming here and inviting him to a  wedding like he'll never have.
Loretta considers Chrissy, decides what she's going to do and goes to the flour room.

Many 50 lb. bags of flour are stacked under a bare electr bulb. A rough stone staircase opposite is lit by daylight from above. Ronny, quietly distraught, stands leaning by forehead against a stack of flour. Loretta approaches him She feels for him.
Where you live?
He points to the stone staircase.
Upstairs.
She touches his shoulder.
Come on.
He follows her up the stairs.

location: THE STAIRCASE ENTRANCE ON THE STREET

text: Loretta and Ronny emerge. He gestures. They enter the  apartment building behind the bakery.

It's a dark Italian coffee and dessert house. Reproductio of Roman statuary adorn grottos and alcoves. In the back a glass case displaying various desserts, and behind the  case, a big burnished gold cappuccino machine. The place almost empty.

An album of "NEAPOLITAN FOLK SONGS" is PLAYING on the caf SOUND SYSTEM. The CAMERA TRAVELS along the face of an exposed brick wal DISCOVERING busts of Romans occasionally, and then IT COM TO the figure of COSMO. He's sitting at a table which is  inset into a nook, so we cannot see who he's with.
At a little table away from prying eyes, Cosmo sits with  MONA, his girlfriend. Mona is a pretty but overripe Itali woman in her late forties. She's all done up, and she loo at Cosmo with adoration.
And then there is copper, which is  the only pipe I use. It costs money.  But it costs money because it saves  money.
And what did they say?
The man understood me. The woman  wanted to be cheap, but the man saw  that I was right.
You have such a head for knowing.  You know everything.
I brought you something.
He takes out a small velvet box and hands it to her.
It's a present.
She opens the box. It's a gold bracelet with a pattern of stars and birds.
Oh, Cosmo!
They are little stars and birds.  Birds fly to the stars, I guess.
A three-story walk-up above Cammareri's Bakery.

It's a two-bedroom apartment. The decor reflects Ronny's  love of the opera. The furniture is overstuffed, fringed the colors of Italian passion. But it is all a bit faded, the remains of an old flamboyance. The walls are decorate with opera posters; and over the fireplace there is a pai depicting a scene from "La Boheme": Mimi is standing in t snow. Ronny stares at the picture of Mimi in the La Bohem poster. Loretta comes in from the kitchen and sets down a cup of coffee.
You ready for the coffee?
Loretta moves back into the kitchen. Ronny turns and watc as she walks down the hall.
Loretta. What's that smell?
I'm making you a steak.
You don't have to help me.
I know that. I do what I want.
I like it well done.
You'll eat this bloody to feed your  blood.
CU of Ronny's artificial hand, holding a fork stuck in a  steak. With his right he is cutting his steak. He switche hands and eats hungrily. Loretta watches.
This is good. Uhh...
Loretta.
Where'd Johnny find you?
He knew my husband who died.
How'd he die?
Bus hit him.
Fast.
Instantaneous.
When you get engaged?
Yesterday.
Ronny drops his knife and fork and turns away. Loretta is not surprised and does not move.
Why?
Why what?
I don't know.
(smiles) So. Five years ago your hand got cut  off and your woman left you for  another man. No woman since then?
No.
Stupid.
When your husband get hit by the  bus?
Seven years ago.
How many men since then?
Just Johnny.
Stupid yourself.
No. Unlucky. I have not been lucky.
I don't care about Luck, you  understand me? It ain't that.
What? Do you think you're the only  one ever shed a tear?
Why you talking to me?
You got any whiskey? How 'bout giving  me a glass of whiskey?
The car has just come to a stop. We see Cosmo & Mona kiss She exits car. Cosmo glances around with a slightly guilt look and pulls away.

head_text.subj: LORETTA AND RONNY AT THE TABLE WITH A BOTTLE OF WHISKEY

text: Camera is close on Scotch being poured into two glasses. Loretta picks up her glass and swallows a healthy dose.
She was right to leave me.
You think so?
Yes.
You really are stupid, you know that.
Loretta pours herself another shot.
You don't know nothing about it.

I was raised that a girl gets married  young. I didn't get married until I  was twenty-eight. I met a man. I  loved him. I married him. He wanted  to have a baby right away. I said  no. Then he got hit by a bus. No  man. No baby. No nothing! I did not  know that man was a gift I could not  keep. I didn't know... You tell me a  story and you think you know what it  means, but I see what the true story  is, and you can't. (she pours them both  another drink) She didn't leave you! You can't see  what you are. I can see everything.  You are a wolf!
I'm a wolf?

The big part of you has no words and  it's-a wolf. This woman was a trap  for you. She caught you and you could  not get away. (She grabs his wooden  hand) So you chewed off your foot! That  was the price you had to pay to be  free. (throws his hand down) Johnny had nothing to do with it.  You did what you had to do, between  you and you, and I know I'm right, I  don't care what you say. And now  you're afraid because you found out  the big part of you is a wolf that  has the courage to bite off its own  hand to save itself from the trap of  the wrong love. That's why there has  been no woman since that wrong woman.  You are scared to death what the  wolf will do if you make that mistake  again!
What are you doing!
I'm telling you your life!
Stop it!
No!
Why are you marrying Johnny? He's a  fool!
Because I have no Luck!
(pounding on the table) He made me look the wrong way and I  cut off my hand. He could make you  look the wrong way and you could cut  off your whole head!
I am looking where I should to become  a bride!
A bride without a head!
A wolf without a foot!

Ronny stiff-arms everything off the dining table and grab Loretta. They kiss passionately. He pulls her up on the t and over the table to him. They are in each other's arms. They are on fire. Loretta pushes him away, gasping for ai
Wait a minute! Wait a minute!
She changes her mind and lunges into another kiss. They s again after a long moment. They really haven't breathed. They both suck in air and look at each other in wonder an fear and passion.
It's like I'm falling! It's like I'm  in the ocean!
They kiss again. When they pull apart again, Loretta is  crying.
I have no Luck!
He picks her up in his arms.
Son of a bitch!
Where are you taking me?
To the bed.
Oh. Oh God. I don't care about  anything. I don't care about anything!  Take me to the bed.
He carries her away, into the bedroom. MUSIC: "O SOAVE FANCIULLA", from "La Boheme." The MUSIC  CONTINUES THROUGH THE NEXT SCENE.
Ronny is laying her down in the bed. He is over her. They look into each other's eyes.
I can't believe what is happening.
Me neither.
I was dead.
I was dead, too.
They kiss. When they part there is a drop of blood on  Loretta's lips.
Your blood.
All my life I have never reached a  man. I knew that I would reach my  husband, but I took my time and he  was dead. Ronny.
Loretta.
I want to cut you open and crawl  inside of you. I want you to swallow  me.
I've got you.
Get all of me. Take everything.
What about Johnny?
You're mad at him, take it out on  me, take your revenge on me! Take  everything, leave nothing for him to  marry! Hollow me out so there's  nothing left but the skin over my  bones. Suck me dry!
Alright. Alright. There will be  nothing left.
Their eyes are boiling with fierce animal tears. They hav opened their souls to each other and they are coming toge The MUSIC SWELLS to a terrible triumph.
Dog whines over exterior.
With five beds for dogs. Four of the beds are empty and o the fifth Judas is whining. He looks around at the other  beds. Where is everybody? He goes out the bedroom door.

Judas is running down the stairs and into the hall. We FO HIM down the hall. The hall is only dimly lit. He finds t four other dogs. They are crowded at a narrow doorway. From the doorway comes a golden light.

head_text.subj: THE PLEASED FACE OF COSMO THROUGH A VEIL OF STEAM

text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK. We are in the Castorini dining room. Cosmo sits at the he of the table, a napkin tucked into his shirt. Rose has just laid down a massive platter of steaming bak fish. Already on the table is a platter of pasta, loaves bread, a big bowl of salad, two bottles of wine, and an  appetizer plate of salami and pimento. Seated at the tabl is COSMO, the Old Man, and RAYMOND and RITA CAPPOMAGGI. Raymond is rotund, moon-faced, bald, somewhere in his fif He has a pencil-thin mustache over his small mouth. His w Rita, looks very like him, except she has hair on her hea and none on her lip. Raymond is Rose's brother. There are two empty places at table, for Rose and Loretta.
Where's Loretta? We're gonna start  without her.

head_text.subj: ONE OF THE ENTRANCE WAYS TO THE DINING ROOM

text: There is an accordion gate across it. Behind the gate, th Five Dogs stare at the people having dinner.
She must be eating out.
She don't know what she's missing.
It's not like her not to call.
Well, she's got a lot on her mind.
I mean, can we talk about it, Rose?  Everybody's heard. She's getting  married again.
I don't wanna talk about it.
Johnny Cammareri. I think it's great  and about time. What's she gonna do  with the rest of her life she don't  get married?
I don't wanna talk about it.

The Old Man has piled his plate high with food. Now he st up, walks over to the Dogs, and puts the plate down in th midst. The Dogs attack the food and each other. The Old M walks back to the table and sits down. He looks down at t empty place in front of him, a little sad.
My father needs a plate.
Rose gets another plate from a sideboard and puts it in f of the Old Man. He immediately, methodically begins to fi his new plate. Rose goes to her place and sits down.
Cosmo. Many years ago, when they  told me you were marrying my sister,  I was happy. When I told Rose I was  marrying Rita, she was happy.
Marriage is happy news.
The Old Man laughs uproariously, subsides, goes back to  filling his plate.
Rose, pass the wine.

I never seen anybody so in love like  Cosmo back then! He'd stand outside  the house all day and look in the  windows. I never told you this cause  it's not really a story. But one  time I woke up in the middle of the  night cause this bright light was in  my face. Like a flashlight. I couldn't  think a what it was. I looked out  the window, and it was the moon! Big  as a house! I never seen the moon so  big before or since. I was almost  scared, like it was gonna crush the  house. And I looked down, and standing  there in the street was Cosmo, looking  up at the windows. This is the funny  part. I got mad at you, Cosmo! I  thought you brought this big moon  over to my house cause you were so  in love and woke me up with it. I  was half asleep I guess and didn't  know no better.
You were altogether asleep. You were  dreaming.
No. You were there.
Raymond stares at Cosmo, nodding, remembering. There's a  lull at the table, the SOUND of SILVERWARE.
I don't wanna talk about it.
(suddenly angry) Well, what do you wanna talk about!
Rita. Pass the wine.
Why you drinking so much?
The Old Man gets up with his newly filled plate and heads for the Dogs.
Old Man, if you give another piece  of my food to those dogs, I'm gonna  kick you till you're dead!
The Old Man reverses direction and heads back to his chai He sits down and starts to eat.
Over the house is a great big full moon.
The lights in the bedroom are still on. Cosmo is in bed, his pajamas, asleep. Rose comes in her nightgown. She loo at Cosmo. He's snoring lightly.
Cosmo?
He doesn't stir. She goes to him and runs her hand throug his hair.
You drank too much and now you sleep  too hard, and later you'll be up  when you should be down.

She kisses his cheek. Then she turns out the lights. When the electric lights go out, moonlight floods the room. Sh goes to the window and looks out through the curtains at moon. Rose puts her face in her hands and quietly cries.
RESUME INT. CASTORINI HOUSE - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT (Ros crying.
The bedroom is flooded by moonlight. Loretta wakes up, a  little alarmed.
What's that?
Ronny wakes up, a little alarmed.
What?
That light.
I don't know. I think it's the moon.
Loretta goes to the window wrapped in a white sheet from bed. The window is glowing with moonlight. The moonlight  strikes her, and she is caught in its spell.
Oh.
Ronny appears behind her, pulling on a robe. They speak i low voices, as if they were in church.
It's so bright.
I've never seen a moon like that.
It makes you look like an angel.
She turns and looks at him. They kiss. They break apart. Ronny looks up at the moon.
Yeah. Looks like a big snowball.
Shot of the house with the moon overhead.

There is a big window right by the bed, and in the window the moon. Raymond and Rita are in their bed, asleep. Raym wakes up, and sees the moon in the window. He's stunned a excited, but he too speaks in this low voice of respect.
Rita. Rita.
(waking up) What? What?
Look.
Oh.
It's Cosmo's moon.
What are you talking about, Raymond?  Cosmo can't own the moon.
I mean it's that moon I was talking  about at dinner. (looks through the  window, down into  the street) Is he down there? No.
Is who down there?
Cosmo.
What would he be doing down there?
I don't know.
You know, in this light, and with  that expression on your face, you  look about twenty-five years old.
Raymond smiles at her meekly.

Over the house is still the great big full moon. The fron door opens and out comes the Old Man with the five Dogs. The Old Man is in a greatcoat and a felt hat, and he's sm a cigar. He stops on the top step and lets go a huge plum of cigar smoke. Then he starts off with the Dogs down the street.

The moon and nothing else. Then a cigar is thrown into it and sends it shimmering. It was the moon reflected in wat Now the CAMERA PULLS BACK and WE SEE the Old Man and the  Five Dogs are standing on a ruined pier. The moon gleams from the Hudson River. The Old Man speaks to the Dogs.
Alright now. Howl. Howl.

The Dogs do not howl. So the Old Man, by way of demonstra howls at the moon. He looks to the Dogs to follow suit. T do nothing. He howls at the moon again. The Dogs do nothing. The CAMERA CONTINUES TO PULL BACK un WE CAN SEE the whole pier, with the Old Man and the Dogs it, and the moon above them. The Old Man, frustrated now, cries out.
How long must I wait? Quanto tempo  devo aspettare!
The Dogs start to HOWL. The Old Man, pleased as the Mad H he is, laughs and laughs.
Transition from moon reflecting in the water to dawn.
Morning sun floods the room. Close on Loretta, she wakes
Oh my God.
What?
Loretta jumps from bed, grabs her clothes to cover hersel and backs into closet.
What? What have we done?
(perturbed) Take it easy.
(from closet as she  hurriedly gets dressed) This time I was trying to do  everything right.
(he grabs a bathrobe,  pulls it on, puts it  on and moves towards  the closet.) Don't just become excited.
I thought if I stayed away from the  City Hall, I won't have that Bad  Luck I had again.
You're trying to make me feel guilty.
I'm marrying your brother!
All right, I'm guilty. I confess!
You're invited to the wedding! It's  in a few weeks. Why didn't you do  like him and be with your dying mother  in Palermo?
She didn't like me.
You don't get along with anybody!
What did you do?
What did I do?
You ruined my life.
That's impossible! It was ruint when  I got here! You ruint my life!
Oh no I didn't!
Loretta emerges from the closet, tucking in her blouse.

Oh yes, oh yes you did! You've got  those bad eyes like a gypsy! Why  didn't I see it yesterday! Bad Luck!  Is that all I'm ever gonna have? Why  didn't I just pick up a stone and  kill myself years and years ago? I'm  gonna marry him!
What?
Last night never happened, you hear  me? I'm gonna marry him anyway and  last night never happened, and you  and I are gonna take this to our  coffins!
I can't do that!
Why not?
I'm in love with you!
Loretta stares at him in alarm, slaps his face, then stud his face to see the effect of the slap. She is dissatisfi and slaps him again.
Snap out of it!
I can't!
Alright. Then I must never see you  again. The bad blood will have to  stay there between you and Johnny  for all time. You won't come to the  wedding.
I'll come to the wedding.
I'm telling you you can't.
But he wants me to come!
But that's cause he don't know!
Alright. I will not come. Provided  one thing.
What?
That you come with me tonight. Once.  To the Opera.
What are you talking about?
I love two things. I love you, and I  love the Opera. If I can have the  two things that I love together for  one night, I will be satisfied to  give up the rest of my life.
Alright.
Alright. Meet me at the Met.
Alright. Where's the Met?

Camera moves from stained glass windows to confessional. Loretta is next in line of THREE SINNERS waiting to go in the confessional. A FORGIVEN WOMAN emerges from the curta booth and walks off to pay her penance. Loretta goes into the booth.
Loretta kneels. The slide opens and an OLD PRIEST'S FACE be seen in outline through the screen.
Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.  It's been two months since my last  confession.
What sins have you to confess?
Twice I took the name of God in vain,  once I slept with the brother of my  fiance, and once I bounced a check  at the liquor store -- but that was  really an accident.
Then it was not a sin. But what was  that second thing you said, Loretta?
I... a... slept with my fiance's  brother.
That's a pretty big sin.
I know.
You should think about this.
I know.
Alright. This is your penance. Say  two rosaries and... be careful,  Loretta. Reflect on your life.
Alright.
I absolve you in the name of the  Father, and of the Son, and of the  Holy Spirit, Amen.

Loretta comes out of the confessional and enters a pew. S crosses herself. Then she recognizes the back of a woman' head a few pews down. She gets up, walks down the aisle, kneels down next to her mother, Rose.
Hi.
(looking up from her  prayers) Where you been?
I don't wanna talk about it.
Just like your father. I lied to  him. He thinks you came home last  night.
Thanks. What's the matter with you?
Cosmo's cheating on me.
What! How do you know?
A wife knows.
Then you don't know. You're just  imagining it. He's too old.
Rose starts to reply, but then decides it's not worth the argument.
I won't be home for dinner.
Loretta crosses herself quickly, gets up, and leaves. Ros looks after, and then goes back to her prayer.

Feminine hands apply the final decorative touches of blue icing to a wedding cake. Then the hands set the plastic b and groom on the pinnacle. The CAMERA PULLS BACK. Barbara is viewing her handiwork, a wedding cake on a  stainless steel wheeled cart. She's in the back part of t bakery. Barbara is pleased with her creation. We TRAVEL W HER as she rolls the cart out to the front of the store w Chrissy is waiting on a huge man named HARVEY. She hands a tiny box, which he takes meekly.
See you tomorrow, Chrissy.
Okay, Harvey.
Harvey lumbers off as Barbara enters the front of the sto with the cake on its cart. Barbara calls Chrissy's attent to the cake.
So what do you think?
About what?
The cake!
(without enthusiasm) Where's Ronny? How come he ain't  come down?
How should I know?
The PHONE RINGS. Chrissy answers it.
Hello, Cammareri's? Hi. Uh-huh. Okay.
She hangs up.
That was Ronny. He don't feel good.  He ain't gonna be down today.
Chrissy comes out from behind the counter. She's staring the cake.
What, is he still upset?
Without warning, Chrissy whacks the little bride and groo off the cake and on to the floor.
It's that bitch!
Barbara looks at her, shocked.
An Italian specialty store in Little Italy.
